item.title: Visual Representation & Visible Boundaries in Online Postpartum Depression Support Groups
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 73-88, April 2023.
The American Psychological Association notes that approximately one in seven women will experience postpartum depression (PPD) after giving birth. Finding support can help lead to better outcomes for those suffering from PPD. This article examines cover photos of PPD support groups on Facebook. By arguing that these photos construct rhetorical boundaries that support-seekers must cross to access PPD resources, the article expands our current understandings of rhetorical boundaries and calls for increased attention to visual selection in high-stakes health contexts. This article emphasizes the idea that we might transform visual boundaries, like the Facebook cover photos studied here, into rhetorical boundary objects that promote inclusivity through more thoughtful and representative image selection.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 73-88, April 2023.
The American Psychological Association notes that approximately one in seven women will experience postpartum depression (PPD) after giving birth. Finding support can help lead to better outcomes for those suffering from PPD. This article examines cover photos of PPD support groups on Facebook. By arguing that these photos construct rhetorical boundaries that support-seekers must cross to access PPD resources, the article expands our current understandings of rhetorical boundaries and calls for increased attention to visual selection in high-stakes health contexts. This article emphasizes the idea that we might transform visual boundaries, like the Facebook cover photos studied here, into rhetorical boundary objects that promote inclusivity through more thoughtful and representative image selection.
item.dc:title: Visual Representation & Visible Boundaries in Online Postpartum Depression Support Groups
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Shannon Fanning
item.prism:publicationName: Visual Representation & Visible Boundaries in Online Postpartum Depression Support Groups

item.title: Identifying Digital Rhetoric in the Telemedicine User Interface
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 89-105, April 2023.
Telemedicine is an alternative healthcare delivery system whereby patients access digital technology to consult with a physician virtually. Patients first interact with telemedicine via a consumer-facing website. Telemedicine promises numerous benefits to patients, such as increased access to healthcare, yet poor usability of the telemedicine user interface (UI) may hinder patient acceptance and adoption of the service. The telemedicine UI moderates patients’ ability to utilize telemedicine, and therefore it must be usable, but it must also be rhetorical to motivate patients to perform certain actions. Digital rhetoric refers to UI elements that influence user actions and knowledge and is tied to usability because of these same human–computer interaction (HCI) factors. This study examined the usability of three telemedicine provider UIs and by identifying usability problems, reveals digital rhetoric that is significant to telemedicine UIs. The article concludes by offering heuristics of digital rhetoric that lead to optimal usability.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 89-105, April 2023.
Telemedicine is an alternative healthcare delivery system whereby patients access digital technology to consult with a physician virtually. Telemedicine promises numerous benefits to patients, such as increased access to healthcare, yet poor usability of the telemedicine user interface (UI) may hinder patient acceptance and adoption of the service. The telemedicine UI moderates patients’ ability to utilize telemedicine, and therefore it must be usable, but it must also be rhetorical to motivate patients to perform certain actions. Digital rhetoric refers to UI elements that influence user actions and knowledge and is tied to usability because of these same human–computer interaction (HCI) factors. This study examined the usability of three telemedicine provider UIs and by identifying usability problems, reveals digital rhetoric that is significant to telemedicine UIs. The article concludes by offering heuristics of digital rhetoric that lead to optimal usability.
item.dc:title: Identifying Digital Rhetoric in the Telemedicine User Interface
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Jessica Lynn Campbell
item.prism:publicationName: Identifying Digital Rhetoric in the Telemedicine User Interface

item.title: Visualizing a Drug Abuse Epidemic: Media Coverage, Opioids, and the Racialized Construction of Public Health Frameworks
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 106-127, April 2023.
In technical and professional communication, the social justice turn calls on us to interrogate sites of positionality, privilege, and power to help foreground strategies that can empower marginalized groups. I propose that mainstream media coverage of the opioid epidemic represents such a site because addiction to these drugs, which initially primarily affected White people, has been positioned as a public health issue rather than a criminal justice problem. I explore the strategies that were used to create this positioning by investigating themes in the visual rhetoric as conveyed through data visualizations and in the text of the articles in which these graphics were published. My results align with two previous studies that confirmed this public health framing. I also observed an emphasis on mortality, which contributes to our understanding of rhetorical strategies that can be used to engender support rather than condemnation for those suffering from drug addiction.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 106-127, April 2023.

My results align with two previous studies that confirmed this public health framing. I also observed an emphasis on mortality, which contributes to our understanding of rhetorical strategies that can be used to engender support rather than condemnation for those suffering from drug addiction.
item.dc:title: Visualizing a Drug Abuse Epidemic: Media Coverage, Opioids, and the Racialized Construction of Public Health Frameworks
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Candice A. Welhausen
item.prism:publicationName: Visualizing a Drug Abuse Epidemic: Media Coverage, Opioids, and the Racialized Construction of Public Health Frameworks

item.title: Examining Multimodal Community-Engaged Projects for Technical and Professional Communication: Motivation, Design, Technology, and Impact
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 128-159, April 2023.
This study examines the role of multimodality in facilitating service-learning goals. We report findings from qualitative interviews with 20 college instructors who have designed and facilitated multimodal community-engaged learning projects, identifying their motivations, goals, and the impact of these projects through reflections. Based on our qualitative analysis of these instructor responses, we discuss the technological and pedagogical implications of multimodal social advocacy projects in technical and professional writing courses.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Volume 53, Issue 2, Page 128-159, April 2023.
This study examines the role of multimodality in facilitating service-learning goals. We report findings from qualitative interviews with 20 college instructors who have designed and facilitated multimodal community-engaged learning projects, identifying their motivations, goals, and the impact of these projects through reflections. Based on our qualitative analysis of these instructor responses, we discuss the technological and pedagogical implications of multimodal social advocacy projects in technical and professional writing courses.
item.dc:title: Examining Multimodal Community-Engaged Projects for Technical and Professional Communication: Motivation, Design, Technology, and Impact
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Jason Tham
Jialei Jiang
item.prism:publicationName: Examining Multimodal Community-Engaged Projects for Technical and Professional Communication: Motivation, Design, Technology, and Impact

item.title: Emojination Facilitates Inclusive Emoji Design Through Technical Writing: Fitting Tactical Technical Communication Inside Institutional Structures
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Creating new emojis is predicated on a system of technical writing that lobbies for new emojis to the Unicode Consortium. Emojination, an activist collective working for cultural inclusivity, helps everyday people write proposals for inclusive and culturally sensitive emojis. Through a case study of Emojination, this article describes ways that Tactical Technical Communication can work toward cultural inclusivity within regulatory frameworks.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Creating new emojis is predicated on a system of technical writing that lobbies for new emojis to the Unicode Consortium. Emojination, an activist collective working for cultural inclusivity, helps everyday people write proposals for inclusive and culturally sensitive emojis. Through a case study of Emojination, this article describes ways that Tactical Technical Communication can work toward cultural inclusivity within regulatory frameworks.
item.dc:title: Emojination Facilitates Inclusive Emoji Design Through Technical Writing: Fitting Tactical Technical Communication Inside Institutional Structures
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: John R. Gallagher
Rebecca E. Avgoustopoulos
item.prism:publicationName: Emojination Facilitates Inclusive Emoji Design Through Technical Writing: Fitting Tactical Technical Communication Inside Institutional Structures

item.title: Conferences With the Engineers: The Innovative Pedagogy and Career of Sada Harbarger, 1884–1942
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
While Sada Harbarger is primarily known as the author of the first genre-based technical communication textbook, 1923's English For Engineers, I argue through extensive archival materials that her innovative conferencing with engineering students and interdisciplinary writing efforts, rather, drove her interwar success at Ohio State. Her rural agricultural background and acquaintance with the engineering faculty, combined with her literature training, led to OSU's engineering faculty demanding successfully that English promote her without reference to her textbook. Harbarger is also a notable early example of navigating being a female professor teaching engineering writing in a male-dominated English literature department.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
While Sada Harbarger is primarily known as the author of the first genre-based technical communication textbook, 1923's English For Engineers, I argue through extensive archival materials that her innovative conferencing with engineering students and interdisciplinary writing efforts, rather, drove her interwar success at Ohio State. Her rural agricultural background and acquaintance with the engineering faculty, combined with her literature training, led to OSU's engineering faculty demanding successfully that English promote her without reference to her textbook. Harbarger is also a notable early example of navigating being a female professor teaching engineering writing in a male-dominated English literature department.
item.dc:title: Conferences With the Engineers: The Innovative Pedagogy and Career of Sada Harbarger, 1884–1942
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Mike Duncan
item.prism:publicationName: Conferences With the Engineers: The Innovative Pedagogy and Career of Sada Harbarger, 1884–1942

item.title: A Field Wide Snapshot of Student Learning Outcomes in the Technical and Professional Communication Service Course
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Using the technical and professional communication service course as the site for research, and student learning outcomes (SLOs) as the specific focus, we gathered, coded, and analyzed 503 SLOs from 93 institutions. Our results show the top outcomes are rhetoric, genre, writing, design, and collaboration. We discuss these outcomes and then we offer programmatic implications drawn from the data that encourage technical and professional communication program administrators and faculty to use common SLOs, to improve outcome development, and to reconsider the purpose of the service course for students.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Using the technical and professional communication service course as the site for research, and student learning outcomes (SLOs) as the specific focus, we gathered, coded, and analyzed 503 SLOs from 93 institutions. We discuss these outcomes and then we offer programmatic implications drawn from the data that encourage technical and professional communication program administrators and faculty to use common SLOs, to improve outcome development, and to reconsider the purpose of the service course for students.
item.dc:title: A Field Wide Snapshot of Student Learning Outcomes in the Technical and Professional Communication Service Course
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Jessica Griffith
Tanya Zarlengo
Lisa Melonçon
item.prism:publicationName: A Field Wide Snapshot of Student Learning Outcomes in the Technical and Professional Communication Service Course

item.title: Implementing a Continuous Improvement Model for Assignment Evaluation at the Technical and Professional Communication Program Level
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
We use a continuous improvement model to evaluate an information design assignment by analyzing 120 student drafts and finals alongside instructor feedback. Using data from across sections (N = 118), we illustrate a process focused on improving student learning that other technical and professional communication program administrators and faculty can follow, while also offering insights into ways programs can assist a contingent labor force with improving pedagogical practice. This study provides insights into assignment design through data-driven evidence and reflective work that is necessary to help continuously improve a service course and to assist students in meeting learning outcomes.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
We use a continuous improvement model to evaluate an information design assignment by analyzing 120 student drafts and finals alongside instructor feedback. Using data from across sections (N = 118), we illustrate a process focused on improving student learning that other technical and professional communication program administrators and faculty can follow, while also offering insights into ways programs can assist a contingent labor force with improving pedagogical practice. This study provides insights into assignment design through data-driven evidence and reflective work that is necessary to help continuously improve a service course and to assist students in meeting learning outcomes.
item.dc:title: Implementing a Continuous Improvement Model for Assignment Evaluation at the Technical and Professional Communication Program Level
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Michelle Sonnenberg
Carolyn Gubala
Justiss Burry
Jessica Griffith
Tanya Zarlengo
Lisa Melonçon
item.prism:publicationName: Implementing a Continuous Improvement Model for Assignment Evaluation at the Technical and Professional Communication Program Level

item.title: Don’t Abbreviate: An Experimental Comparison of the U.S. State Display Designs Commonly Used in Surveys and Forms*
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Forms and surveys often require address information, including state. State data entry fields in online forms typically use a dropdown where the user selects one state from the list. A review of online forms shows a variety of state lists used, with some including the state name fully spelled out while others use the state abbreviation, and still others use a combination of the two, like MD-Maryland. Through a series of three independent experiments, we investigate usability of state list designs as measured by time-on-task, accuracy of answers, or user preference. Results indicate that participants have difficulty with state abbreviations alone. That design results in longer time-on-task, and lower accuracy and preference, particularly for states where the user does not live. We did not find any significant difference in usability for full state names compared to the abbreviation and state name combination in a dropdown design.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Forms and surveys often require address information, including state. State data entry fields in online forms typically use a dropdown where the user selects one state from the list. A review of online forms shows a variety of state lists used, with some including the state name fully spelled out while others use the state abbreviation, and still others use a combination of the two, like MD-Maryland. Through a series of three independent experiments, we investigate usability of state list designs as measured by time-on-task, accuracy of answers, or user preference. Results indicate that participants have difficulty with state abbreviations alone. That design results in longer time-on-task, and lower accuracy and preference, particularly for states where the user does not live. We did not find any significant difference in usability for full state names compared to the abbreviation and state name combination in a dropdown design.
item.dc:title: Don’t Abbreviate: An Experimental Comparison of the U.S. State Display Designs Commonly Used in Surveys and Forms*
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Nichols
Erica Olmsted-Hawala
Shelley Feuer
Lin Wang
item.prism:publicationName: Don’t Abbreviate: An Experimental Comparison of the U.S. State Display Designs Commonly Used in Surveys and Forms*

item.title: You Shall Not Pass? The Design of Age Gates in an Emerging Cannabis Market
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Age gates are becoming common on the websites of cannabis dispensaries, following design practices in other controversial industries. Yet, age gates can typically be bypassed through trial and error or basic arithmetic, raising questions over best practices. This study therefore characterized the age gates of dispensaries licensed in the Arizona adult use cannabis program, using a “digital mystery shopper” approach to examine the age gates’ location, appearance, and performance. After presenting the results, I outline possible best practices and next steps for technical and professional communicators.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Age gates are becoming common on the websites of cannabis dispensaries, following design practices in other controversial industries. Yet, age gates can typically be bypassed through trial and error or basic arithmetic, raising questions over best practices. This study therefore characterized the age gates of dispensaries licensed in the Arizona adult use cannabis program, using a “digital mystery shopper” approach to examine the age gates’ location, appearance, and performance. After presenting the results, I outline possible best practices and next steps for technical and professional communicators.
item.dc:title: You Shall Not Pass? The Design of Age Gates in an Emerging Cannabis Market
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Michael J. Madson
item.prism:publicationName: You Shall Not Pass? The Design of Age Gates in an Emerging Cannabis Market

item.title: Collaborating Successfully with Community Partners and Clients in Online Service-Learning Classes
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Teaching online students to collaborate effectively with community partners and to solve problems through service-learning projects are “on trend” topics for technical communication faculty. This article presents collaboration specifics as well as the author's Collaborative Communication Framework (CCF) to show the types of communication needed to work well with community partners/clients in service-learning. Tips for teaching, including using the CCF and service-learning, will be highlighted so faculty can make choices about how to meet curricular goals while addressing community partner/client needs. Resources for teaching will be offered. Successful student projects will show detailed examples of key ideas throughout the article.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Teaching online students to collaborate effectively with community partners and to solve problems through service-learning projects are “on trend” topics for technical communication faculty. This article presents collaboration specifics as well as the author's Collaborative Communication Framework (CCF) to show the types of communication needed to work well with community partners/clients in service-learning. Tips for teaching, including using the CCF and service-learning, will be highlighted so faculty can make choices about how to meet curricular goals while addressing community partner/client needs. Resources for teaching will be offered. Successful student projects will show detailed examples of key ideas throughout the article.
item.dc:title: Collaborating Successfully with Community Partners and Clients in Online Service-Learning Classes
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Rebecca J. Dumlao
item.prism:publicationName: Collaborating Successfully with Community Partners and Clients in Online Service-Learning Classes

item.title: Tactical Technical Communication and Player-Created (DIY) Patch Notes: A Case Study
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Relying on rhetorical analysis, this article explores the rhetoric and ethics of a particular type of designer- and player-created technical communication genre, video patch notes, to further explore how various technical communication genres structure the experience of play. By providing a case study of official video patch notes for the game Overwatch in combination with Youtube user dinoflask's satirical fan made videos, the article examines both developers’ communication practices and the ways in which players creatively negotiate and re-purpose these practices in order to illustrate how such tactical technical communication remixes sustain a subtle dialogue between players and developers. This dialogue in particular illuminates pain points between stakeholders (in this case, discrepancies between developer intent and player experience) in ways that could potentially offer a means of persuading particularly ideologically fixed audiences, highlighting how practitioners might use tactical technical communication with activist intent.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
Relying on rhetorical analysis, this article explores the rhetoric and ethics of a particular type of designer- and player-created technical communication genre, video patch notes, to further explore how various technical communication genres structure the experience of play. By providing a case study of official video patch notes for the game Overwatch in combination with Youtube user dinoflask's satirical fan made videos, the article examines both developers’ communication practices and the ways in which players creatively negotiate and re-purpose these practices in order to illustrate how such tactical technical communication remixes sustain a subtle dialogue between players and developers. This dialogue in particular illuminates pain points between stakeholders (in this case, discrepancies between developer intent and player experience) in ways that could potentially offer a means of persuading particularly ideologically fixed audiences, highlighting how practitioners might use tactical technical communication with activist intent.
item.dc:title: Tactical Technical Communication and Player-Created (DIY) Patch Notes: A Case Study
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Caravella
Steve Holmes
item.prism:publicationName: Tactical Technical Communication and Player-Created (DIY) Patch Notes: A Case Study

item.title: Slow Civic Violence and the Removal of USPS Mail Sorting Machines During the 2020 Election
item.content:encoded:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
This article combines historical research with demographic analysis and neoliberal/rhetorical critique to put forth the concept of slow civic violence—indirect injuries on civic process, particularly within marginalized communities. The author ties the United States Postal Service's (USPS) rationale for removing mail sorting machines during the 2020 election year to systemic moves that damage democratic participation. The author conducts an empirical analysis of where the USPS mail sorting machines were removed to show how neoliberal arguments in favor of cost cutting make voting by mail a more precarious and uncertain act primarily for those who reside in communities of color.
item.description:
Journal of Technical Writing and Communication, Ahead of Print.
This article combines historical research with demographic analysis and neoliberal/rhetorical critique to put forth the concept of slow civic violence—indirect injuries on civic process, particularly within marginalized communities. The author conducts an empirical analysis of where the USPS mail sorting machines were removed to show how neoliberal arguments in favor of cost cutting make voting by mail a more precarious and uncertain act primarily for those who reside in communities of color.
item.dc:title: Slow Civic Violence and the Removal of USPS Mail Sorting Machines During the 2020 Election
item.dc:source: Journal of Technical Writing and Communication
item.dc:creator: Fernando Sánchez
item.prism:publicationName: Slow Civic Violence and the Removal of USPS Mail Sorting Machines During the 2020 Election
